articles.title: Breakthrough optical processor lets AI compute at the speed of light
articles.summary: Researchers at Tsinghua University developed the Optical Feature Extraction Engine (OFE2), an optical engine that processes data at 12.5 GHz using light rather than electricity. Its integrated diffraction and data preparation modules enable unprecedented speed and efficiency for AI tasks. Demonstrations in imaging and trading showed improved accuracy, lower latency, and reduced power demand. This innovation pushes optical computing toward real-world, high-performance AI.
articles.content:
Modern artificial intelligence (AI) systems, from robotic surgery to high-frequency trading, rely on processing streams of raw data in real time. Extracting important features quickly is critical, but conventional digital processors are hitting physical limits. Traditional electronics can no longer reduce latency or increase throughput enough to keep up with today's data-heavy applications.

Turning to Light for Faster Computing

Researchers are now looking to light as a solution. Optical computing -- using light instead of electricity to handle complex calculations -- offers a way to dramatically boost speed and efficiency. One promising approach involves optical diffraction operators, thin plate-like structures that perform mathematical operations as light passes through them. These systems can process many signals at once with low energy use. However, maintaining the stable, coherent light needed for such computations at speeds above 10 GHz has proven extremely difficult.

To overcome this challenge, a team led by Professor Hongwei Chen at Tsinghua University in China developed a groundbreaking device known as the Optical Feature Extraction Engine, or OFE2. Their work, published in Advanced Photonics Nexus, demonstrates a new way to perform high-speed optical feature extraction suitable for multiple real-world applications.

How OFE2 Prepares and Processes Data

A key advance in OFE2 is its innovative data preparation module. Supplying fast, parallel optical signals to the core optical components without losing phase stability is one of the toughest problems in the field. Fiber-based systems often introduce unwanted phase fluctuations when splitting and delaying light. The Tsinghua team solved this by designing a fully integrated on-chip system with adjustable power splitters and precise delay lines. This setup converts serial data into several synchronized optical channels. In addition, an integrated phase array allows OFE2 to be easily reconfigured for different computational tasks.

Once prepared, the optical signals pass through a diffraction operator that performs the feature extraction. This process is similar to a matrix-vector multiplication, where light waves interact to create focused "bright spots" at specific output points. By fine-tuning the phase of the input light, these spots can be directed toward chosen output ports, enabling OFE2 to capture subtle variations in the input data over time.

Record-Breaking Optical Performance

Operating at an impressive 12.5 GHz, OFE2 achieves a single matrix-vector multiplication in just 250.5 picoseconds -- the fastest known result for this type of optical computation. "We firmly believe this work provides a significant benchmark for advancing integrated optical diffraction computing to exceed a 10 GHz rate in real-world applications," says Chen.

The research team tested OFE2 across multiple domains. In image processing, it successfully extracted edge features from visual data, creating paired "relief and engraving" maps that improved image classification and increased accuracy in tasks such as identifying organs in CT scans. Systems using OFE2 required fewer electronic parameters than standard AI models, proving that optical preprocessing can make hybrid AI networks both faster and more efficient.

The team also applied OFE2 to digital trading, where it processed live market data to generate profitable buy and sell actions. After being trained with optimized strategies, OFE2 converted incoming price signals directly into trading decisions, achieving consistent returns. Because these calculations happen at the speed of light, traders could act on opportunities with almost no delay.

Lighting the Way Toward the Future of AI

Together, these achievements signal a major shift in computing. By moving the most demanding parts of AI processing from power-hungry electronic chips to lightning-fast photonic systems, technologies like OFE2 could usher in a new era of real-time, low-energy AI. "The advancements presented in our study push integrated diffraction operators to a higher rate, providing support for compute-intensive services in areas such as image recognition, assisted healthcare, and digital finance. We look forward to collaborating with partners who have data-intensive computational needs," concludes Chen.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant technological breakthrough in optical computing that enables AI to process data at unprecedented speeds and efficiency, with demonstrated applications in healthcare imaging and financial trading. This innovation has broad implications for improving AI performance and energy consumption in multiple real-world domains, representing a meaningful advance with tangible benefits.
articles.personality_title: New optical processor lets AI work at the speed of light
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Artificial intelligence (AI) systems need to process large amounts of data very quickly, but traditional electronic processors are reaching their speed limits. This makes it hard for AI to keep up with tasks like robotic surgery or stock trading.

**What happened** – Researchers at Tsinghua University in China created the Optical Feature Extraction Engine (OFE2). This device uses light instead of electricity to process data at 12.5 billion cycles per second (12.5 GHz). It uses tiny optical parts to prepare and analyze data very fast and accurately.

**Impact** – OFE2 is the fastest optical processor of its kind, completing complex calculations in just 250.5 trillionths of a second. It has been tested in medical imaging, helping improve the accuracy of identifying organs in CT scans, and in digital trading, where it made quick decisions based on live market data. It also uses less energy than traditional electronic processors.

**What's next step** – The research team plans to work with companies that need fast and efficient data processing. This technology could be used in more AI applications like healthcare, finance, and other areas where quick decisions are crucial.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The OFE2 optical processor lets AI handle data faster and with less energy by using light, opening new possibilities for real-time applications in medicine and finance.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau processeur optique permet à l'IA de fonctionner à la vitesse de la lumière
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les systèmes d'intelligence artificielle (IA) doivent traiter de grandes quantités de données très rapidement, mais les processeurs électroniques traditionnels atteignent leurs limites de vitesse. Cela complique le travail de l'IA dans des tâches comme la chirurgie robotique ou le trading boursier.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'université Tsinghua en Chine ont créé le moteur d'extraction de caractéristiques optiques (OFE2). Cet appareil utilise la lumière au lieu de l'électricité pour traiter les données à 12,5 milliards de cycles par seconde (12,5 GHz). Il utilise de petites pièces optiques pour préparer et analyser les données très rapidement et avec précision.

**Impact** – L'OFE2 est le processeur optique le plus rapide de son genre, réalisant des calculs complexes en seulement 250,5 billièmes de seconde. Il a été testé en imagerie médicale, améliorant la précision pour identifier des organes dans les scanners, et en trading numérique, où il a pris des décisions rapides basées sur les données du marché en temps réel. Il consomme aussi moins d'énergie que les processeurs électroniques traditionnels.

**Prochaine étape** – L'équipe de recherche prévoit de collaborer avec des entreprises ayant besoin d'un traitement rapide et efficace des données. Cette technologie pourrait être utilisée dans plus d'applications IA comme la santé, la finance, et d'autres domaines nécessitant des décisions rapides.

**En une phrase** – Le processeur optique OFE2 permet à l'IA de traiter les données plus vite et avec moins d'énergie grâce à la lumière, ouvrant de nouvelles possibilités pour des applications en temps réel en médecine et en finance.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo procesador óptico permite a la IA trabajar a la velocidad de la luz
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los sistemas de inteligencia artificial (IA) necesitan procesar grandes cantidades de datos muy rápido, pero los procesadores electrónicos tradicionales están llegando a sus límites de velocidad. Esto dificulta que la IA realice tareas como cirugía robótica o comercio bursátil.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Tsinghua en China crearon el Motor de Extracción de Características Ópticas (OFE2). Este dispositivo usa luz en lugar de electricidad para procesar datos a 12.5 mil millones de ciclos por segundo (12.5 GHz). Utiliza pequeñas piezas ópticas para preparar y analizar datos de forma rápida y precisa.

**Impacto** – OFE2 es el procesador óptico más rápido de su tipo, completando cálculos complejos en solo 250.5 billonésimas de segundo. Se probó en imágenes médicas, mejorando la precisión para identificar órganos en tomografías, y en comercio digital, donde tomó decisiones rápidas basadas en datos del mercado en vivo. También consume menos energía que los procesadores electrónicos tradicionales.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de investigación planea colaborar con empresas que necesitan procesamiento de datos rápido y eficiente. Esta tecnología podría usarse en más aplicaciones de IA como salud, finanzas y otros campos donde las decisiones rápidas son claves.

**Resumen en una frase** – El procesador óptico OFE2 permite que la IA maneje datos más rápido y con menos energía usando luz, abriendo nuevas posibilidades para aplicaciones en tiempo real en medicina y finanzas.

articles.title: More than five million euros of EU funds for Slovenia for the digitalization of geospatial data
articles.summary: The European Regional Development Fund will support the project of the Slovenian Surveying Authority aimed at digitizing in the field of geospatial data with more than five million euros.
articles.content:
The European Regional Development Fund will support the project of the Slovenian Surveying Authority aimed at digitizing in the field of geospatial data with more than five million euros.

Ljubljana – The Slovenian Ministry of Cohesion and Regional Development has approved cohesion funds for the project of the Slovenian Geodetic Administration “Let’s Enter the Digital Space.” The project, with a total value of 9.4 million euros, aimed at digitizing the field of geospatial data, will be supported by the European Regional Development Fund with 5.3 million euros.

The “Let’s Enter the Digital Space” project is, according to the explanations of the Ministry of Cohesion, focused on the development of advanced digital solutions for the collection, analysis, and use of geospatial data and represents an important step towards the digital transformation of the Slovenian space.

Its main goal is to establish a national geospatial digital twin – a virtual model of the physical space that will enable real-time monitoring of events, analyses, simulations, and predictions of changes in space.

An advanced digital data system will be established, based on modern technologies such as laser scanning (lidar), aerial photography, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. This will provide accurate and timely information about the state of the space and enable better decision-making in the fields of spatial planning, real estate management, disaster response, and crisis situations, as well as in planning sustainable development.

With the development of the digital twin, Slovenia, according to the ministry, is following the goals of the Digital Slovenia 2030 strategy, in which the establishment of a digital twin is defined as one of the central measures to accelerate digital innovations and improve the efficiency of public services. The project will also enable the development of advanced digital solutions and services based on geospatial data, artificial intelligence, multidimensional models, and modern visualizations. (October 28)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant public investment in digitizing geospatial data in Slovenia, creating a national digital twin that will enhance real-time monitoring, decision-making, and sustainable development. This represents a meaningful technological advancement with broad societal benefits aligned with national digital transformation goals.
articles.personality_title: Slovenia receives over 5 million euros to create a digital map of the country
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Slovenia is working to improve how it collects and uses information about its land and environment. This type of information, called geospatial data, helps understand physical spaces like cities, forests, and roads.

**What happened** – The European Regional Development Fund is giving more than 5 million euros to Slovenia’s Geodetic Administration for a project called “Let’s Enter the Digital Space.” This project, worth 9.4 million euros in total, will use new technologies to create a detailed digital model of the country.

**Impact** – This digital model, called a national geospatial digital twin, will show real-time changes in the environment. It will help experts and decision-makers plan better for things like city growth, managing properties, responding to disasters, and protecting nature. The project uses advanced tools like laser scanning, aerial photos, and artificial intelligence to gather and analyze data.

**What’s next step** – Slovenia will develop this digital twin over the coming years as part of its Digital Slovenia 2030 plan. This will lead to new digital services that make public work faster and smarter, helping the country manage its land more efficiently.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Slovenia is building a high-tech digital model of its land with EU support to improve planning and protect its environment.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Slovénie reçoit plus de 5 millions d’euros pour créer une carte numérique du pays
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Slovénie cherche à améliorer la collecte et l’utilisation des informations sur son territoire et son environnement. Ces informations, appelées données géospatiales, aident à comprendre les espaces physiques comme les villes, les forêts et les routes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le Fonds européen de développement régional accorde plus de 5 millions d’euros à l’Administration géodésique slovène pour un projet nommé « Entrons dans l’espace numérique ». Ce projet, d’une valeur totale de 9,4 millions d’euros, utilisera de nouvelles technologies pour créer un modèle numérique détaillé du pays.

**Impact** – Ce modèle numérique, appelé jumeau géospatial national, montrera en temps réel les changements dans l’environnement. Il aidera les experts et les décideurs à mieux planifier la croissance des villes, la gestion des propriétés, la réponse aux catastrophes et la protection de la nature. Le projet utilise des outils avancés comme le laser scanning, la photographie aérienne et l’intelligence artificielle pour collecter et analyser les données.

**Prochaine étape** – La Slovénie développera ce jumeau numérique dans les prochaines années dans le cadre de son plan Digital Slovenia 2030. Cela permettra de nouveaux services numériques pour rendre le travail public plus rapide et plus efficace, aidant le pays à mieux gérer son territoire.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La Slovénie construit un modèle numérique haute technologie de son territoire avec le soutien de l’UE pour améliorer la planification et protéger son environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: Eslovenia recibe más de 5 millones de euros para crear un mapa digital del país
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Eslovenia está trabajando para mejorar cómo recoge y utiliza información sobre su tierra y medio ambiente. Esta información, llamada datos geoespaciales, ayuda a entender espacios físicos como ciudades, bosques y carreteras.

**Qué pasó** – El Fondo Europeo de Desarrollo Regional está entregando más de 5 millones de euros a la Administración Geodésica de Eslovenia para un proyecto llamado «Entremos en el Espacio Digital». Este proyecto, con un valor total de 9,4 millones de euros, usará nuevas tecnologías para crear un modelo digital detallado del país.

**Impacto** – Este modelo digital, llamado gemelo digital geoespacial nacional, mostrará cambios en el medio ambiente en tiempo real. Ayudará a expertos y responsables a planificar mejor el crecimiento urbano, la gestión de propiedades, la respuesta a desastres y la protección de la naturaleza. El proyecto usa herramientas avanzadas como escaneo láser, fotografía aérea e inteligencia artificial para recoger y analizar datos.

**Próximo paso** – Eslovenia desarrollará este gemelo digital en los próximos años como parte de su plan Digital Slovenia 2030. Esto dará lugar a nuevos servicios digitales que harán el trabajo público más rápido y eficiente, ayudando al país a gestionar mejor su territorio.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Eslovenia está construyendo un modelo digital de alta tecnología de su territorio con apoyo de la UE para mejorar la planificación y proteger el medio ambiente.
